comments.commentBody:
Followup to Posting 21:

What's a characteristic of someone who claims to have characteristics of both Democrats and Republicans? A person who eats like an elephant and thinks like a jackass. [Note: This is a revision/revival of the original, which I believe was first heard on "The Abbott and Costello Show", a two-year television series in the early 1950s in which the comedians formed half-hour episodes based on their successful films from the 1940s. In this one, Lou (Costello) is running for some office and is campaigning in a park. Bud (Abbott), his campaign manager, tells an audience that gathered around Lou, "Is he a Republican? No! Is he a Democrat? No! He is a combination of a Republican and a Democrat!", which is immediately followed by a heckler (Milt Bronson) shouting, "He sure is! He eats like an elephant and thinks like a jackass!"]

The Democratic Party is two-thirds from the center to the right.

The G. O. P. in years past was a little bit farther right than the Democrats. Now, it is moving towards socialist -- 'National Socialist," I mean.

neither party can fool all of the people all of the time, tht's why there are two. bob hope

libertarians are the party of hypocrites that the tea party wants to join when their IQ gets high enough to make complete sentences

As the holder of a couple of degrees from SUNY, I think it is not exactly correct to treat the State University of New York as one giant monster undergraduate and graduate monolith.  SUNY is made up of several distinctly different university centers and a large number of four year and other colleges located in every corner and area of the state.   Each of these universities, such as Binghamton, Albany, Buffalo, and Stony Brook have different cultures, different sets of courses and professors, and different foci in terms of areas of special interest.  Each of the colleges and universities have their programs and institutions influenced by the interests of the local communities, the local or regional geography,  as well as corporations that are located in their areas or regions.  The makeup of the student bodies also differs considerably across the SUNY spectrum.  For example, Binghamton attracts many foreign students from around the world because of its very major and well developed computer sciences infrastructure that was developed with substantial support, encouragement and input from IBM many decades ago.  Being a magnet for so many foreign students, the university also offers many programs and degrees related to international studies involving sociology, history and anthropology.

One issue that everyone seems to forget re flagship public schools is that the best ones are often located in what are usually considered very desirable places to live. Berkeley, Madision, Charlottesville, Boulder, Seattle, Eugene, Ann Arbor, etc. Consider the locations of the U. California Schools, which include numerous schools that outrank all of the SUNY schools - Santa Barbara, Santa Monica, San Diego,, even Irvine and Santa Cruz. Compare these locations to SUNY locations. Why does location matter? A desirable location is necessary to attract the best faculty and the best students, graduate as well as undergraduate. SUNYs were sited based more on political considerations, for better or for worse, and this will be a difficult problem to overcome.

# 18 : "I do resent the notion that we should pay higher New York State taxes to put someone else's children through school".

"Someone else children" can be one day the doctor who will save your life, the teacher who will teach your grandchildren,or the scientist who will discover a new, cheap source of energy.
By the way, private college is not always better than public even if you payed 10 times more.
My son graduated from SUNY New Paltz and is now happily working for a great,successful company. When they hired him they looked first at his competence, talent, enthusiasm and attitude towards life and work, not if he graduated from Harvard. They know better what makes a good employee.
At least they can just let Maine go via non-tender.  No such luck with Ollie.
Why not bite the bullet on Joba and trade him for a reliable set-up guy?  Some non-contending team might still see him as as a potential future starter.
L. Littlefield (poster#26)- I'd LOVE to see Omar replace Sheldon Silver.  Just get him away from Citifield...

We stayed here 2 years ago, and were very pleased with all aspects of the hotel.  The location is excellent, the breakfast buffet was nice, and the room, very comfortable and quite spacious.  Hotel staff were very helpful.

If you are looking for a classy place to stay on your next visit to Las Vegas, here is a
list of the 10 top hotels in Las Vegas
You just can't go wrong staying in any of these places.

Rajiv this is a great tribute to our mutual friend Chris. Many of your classmates will be attending his Memorial Service Sunday. I know you will be there in spirit. Thank YOU for your service. God Bless YOU!

The M16 was not designed for the Vietnam War.  The came about long before that.  This is common knowledge.  Whoever said M14's are still not being used does not know what they are talking about.  The M-16 has no business as an infantry combat weapon no matter what the many armchair commandoes here would like to believe.  We can do much better.

It is regrettable that the Afghanistan conflict is not yet complete -- more than nine years into the job, longer than World War I, World War I, Korea, and Vietnam -- and yet most of the leaders who cheerled led the country into Afghanistan, and then into Iraq before Afghanistan was secured and bin Laden captured, are now slowly exiting the scene.

In a more perfect world, I suppose, not a single person who led the cheers, from Bush and Cheney, to Wolfowitz, to Perle, to Powell, to Rumsfield, to Rice, to Rove, to McChrystal, to Geraldo, would leave the battlefield until the last soldier departed. Ah, but there mission is only to break things and kill people. Leave the nation building to the diplomats long after so many people have had their lives shattered and destroyed.

I wager that the war even outlasts Gen. Petraeus.

Peter Segal said, of your article, "Trader’s Cocoa Binge Wraps Up Chocolate Market": 'Not much is known about the trader, whose name was William Wonka.'

The world needs such comments in print.

The first meeting for TheJokeWriter.com, attended by 5 top Laugh Lines contributors, took place last week. We agreed to get up and running very soon, providing late night network talk show quality and experience every day, free of charge. Remember to save the URL, or just friend me on Facebook for updates.

According to NYT's numbers, the Court is much more aligned with the country that most of your reader's comments would suggest. I can understand why liberals might not agree with the Court, but the liberal outrage and indignation would be more appropriate if they weren't in the distinct minority.

Seems to me the Court, after long last, isn't conservative -- it's just gone mainstream. How outrageous!

From the ariel shots of the Hockenheim circuit during qualifying I didn't see many cars parked anywhere at all, let alone your own good vehicle.
Is it true that this years German GP is particularly expensive for spectators ?
Yet the crowds seemed good for Q1,2 and 3.

John, that confirms my belief that what the police did to redirect traffic did not help. In fact, this morning, having been warned by yesterday's fiasco, I decided to take the risk of exiting the highway at an exit about 300 yards up the road before the traffic jam. This exit led to the town of Speyer, and I knew that I could get to Hockenheim from Speyer with no problem. In fact, I had no need of getting even close to Speyer once I took this exit, as I ended up basically a couple of minutes drive from Hockenheim and I drove into the circuit in about five minutes from there. And as I drove in I came up in the opposite direction to that massive snake line of cars all being guided by the cops away from the circuit. Oh, well, I'm sure they had their reasons. But I was thankful today not to spend another hour in traffic, instead of the five minutes I spent.

The ticket prices as far as I have been able to learn are the same here as elsewhere in Europe, and I was told the cheapest here are probably around 200 euros, or the cheapest for the three days being around 300 euros. They go up to 5000 euros I think, with the paddock club, and also maybe at least 400 euros for a good seat on the main straight. It is interesting that they expect something like 60,000 people only. And that with a German team and six German drivers. Oh, oh.

I'm coming very late to the fair today, but I did love this puzzle. I read through the clues first, as I often do on a Fri or Sat, and then started in the NW. Got MINIHAHA right away, so the AHA moment was a gimmee, as someone else said (sorry, I can't remember who said it!).
I agree with everything Sara #11 said.

@John Farmer: the Oprah thing reminds me of Paris Hilton's copywriting the word "hot." Have we gone mad?

MOL: I agree that SPAZ is offensive. I found it rather shocking; the other two, not so much, though I do understand others' chagrin.

Thank you for a very fine puzzle! I do think it was Saturday hard but do-able nonetheless, as a good, challenging Sat should be.

This followed what has become a typical pattern for me:  quickly get the two top stacks of words, then, very slowly, figure out where they'll go and how they'll fit together -- one of the most rewarding parts of a crossword solve. This one was especially good as it didn't mention the dreaded Turducken.

Not a puzzle that will bowl one over, but clever, with a theme that stirs up a few giggles but, also, with some clues that stir up a few "huhs?".

Among the "huhs?" are the Saudi province we now know as ASIR; there should be a crossword rule, no provinces other than Canadian ones, perhaps.

Anyone know Erykah BADU, Queen of Neo-Soul? which was crossed with GAUSS which is not the King of Neo-Soul. A bit obscure but certainly gettable from the crosses.

Only two more I'll mention, MONAD which is poaching on our old stand-by basic organism AMOEBA but, hey, a look up tells us that a MONAD is a "flagellated protozoan" so take that, amoeba, you "naked rhizopod".

And, finally, not an obscure clue but a question as to whether the clue "Freezer brand" for EGGO is a legitimate misdirection; for me it is a wonderful clue but others of a more literal bent may feel it is a definite "huh?".

In the theme category I especially liked MOVEMEORLEAVEME and my favorite of the bunch, HOODFORNOTHING.

A puzzle which was Goodforthought, Alan.

Fun, and funny. Loved the Independence Day clue. Pretty easy though, which is actually a nice break from yesterday.

Love those Granada TV Sherlock Holmes shows, though I always preferred Edward Hardwicke as Watson.
A very enjoyable and clever Sunday!!  Liked it mucho.

Congratulations to Alan Arbesfeld for a wonderfully entertaining and gratifying puzzle. The theme was well done and funny, and there were plenty of misdirection clue to winkle out the meaning of. I loved it.
